title: Robinswood Hill Country Park Walking Route

images.title: Derek Harper / Robinswood Hill Country Park
images.caption: Robinswood Hill Country Park. A view across the golf course from the footpath on the eastern slopes of the hill, with the eastern suburbs of Gloucester laid out below.

images.title: Derek Harper / Gloucester from Robinswood Hill
images.caption: View of the city centre, with the cathedral prominent. In the distance, about 20 kilometres away, are the Malvern Hills.

images.title: Bob G / Trigpoint, Robinswood Hill, Gloucestershire
images.caption: Trigpoint. This is the trigpoint at the top of Robinswood Hill, Gloucester and Cheltenham are visible in the distance. The beacon was used during the Golden Jubilee.

images.title: Bob Embleton / Footpath up Robins Wood Hill
images.caption: Looking north east up the hill. The Gloucestershire Wildlife Trust has its head office based in the park. The hill was originally one of the main sources of water to the city of Gloucester. The springs rising on Robin's Wood Hill were used by Gloucester Abbey in the 13th century.

images.title: Derek Harper / Gloucester Golf Club
images.caption: Gloucester Golf Club. A view down a fairway set out down the southern slopes of Robinswood Hill. The course extends beyond the poplars, of which there are two rows. Further away, the line of the M25 crosses the picture in ST8413, with the Cotswold scarp still further away.

images.title: Derek Harper / Sneedhams Green
images.caption: Sneedhams Green. An area of access land enclosing a trio of properties, at the foot of Robinswood Hill.

description: Robinswood Hill country park is located in Gloucester, just to the south of the city centre. The walk explores the 250 acres of park which includes a Local Nature Reserve, an orchard, Robin's Wood Hill Quarry (a Site of Special Scientific Interest) and a dry ski slope. From the 650 ft (198 m) top of Robinswood Hill there are spectacular views of the surrounding area including the Cotswolds, the Malvern Hills, May Hill, the city of Gloucester and on a clear day the Severn Bridges. There's several colour coded walking trails to try including the Fox Trail through the woodland and the Geology trail to the quarry. The area is also great for wildlife with foxes, badgers and red kites to look out for in the skies above.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: There's an on site cafe where you can enjoy a good range of meals and snacks. If you fancy a pub lunch then the Three Oaks Inn is located on the northern side of the park. They have a good range of meals and a nice garden area to sit out in. You can find them at Baneberry Road, GL4 6NR.

details.subtitle: Dog Walking
details.content: The woodland and parkland are an excellent place for a dog walk. You will probably see other dogs running around on your visit. The Three Oaks Inn mentioned above is also dog friendly. The nearby Highnam Woods is another good local option for dog walking.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: A few miles to the east there's another popular local country park in the shape of Crickley Hill. There's more nice trails and another fine viewpoint to be found here. For more walking ideas in the area see the Gloucestershire Walks page.

display_address: Fox Elms Road, Fox Elms, Gloucester, Gloucestershire, England, GL4 0BS, United Kingdom
